div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No.7,558] ALEXANDRIA, MONDAY, JULY 30, 1906. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 1 May to 31 October.
Subjects to the usual 25% reduction for returning.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday until 4 June, and then every Tuesday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.p: OUTWARD to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. “Oruba" will leave Suez about August 10
R.M.S "Ophir" will leave Suez about Aug 24.
HOMEWARD to NAPLES, MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY.
R.M.S. "Ortona" will leave Port Said July 31
R.M.S. “Oroya" will leave Port Said August 14
Passengers returning by the Line obtain one-third rebate off the above fares if leaving England before the end of October.
Agents. Cairo:—Thos. Cook & Son. Alexandria : —R. J. Moss & Co.—For all particulars apply
Wm. STAPLEDON & Sons, PORT SAID and PORT-TEWFIK (Suez). 30-6-906

div.head: BIBBY LINE MAIL TWIN-SCREW STEAMERS.
div.p: REDUCED SUMMER FARES MAY TO OCTOBER.
Port Said to Tilbury £ 12.15.0. and Port Said to Marseilles £ 9.0.0.
Passengers returning by the Line will be granted a rebate of 33% off the full fare i.e. Liverpool to Port Said £ 11.6.8. and Marseilles to Port Said £ 8.0.0.
OUTWARDS to COLOMBO, TUTICORIN, RANGOON. Departure from Suez.
S.S. Derbyshire 6,636 tons, August 3.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON. Departures from Port Said.
S.S. Staffordshire 6,005 tons, August 8.
Agents– Cairo: THOS. COOK & SON. Suez & Port Said : WM. STAPLEDON & SONS,

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at TOR (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Seti now on the berth, will sail on or about Saturday, 11th August, to be followed by S.S. Menes.
S.S Tabor for Havre via Malta to sail about Saturday l5th inst.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo. Particulars on application to
R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

div.head: P. HENDERSON & CO’s LINE.
div.p: Steamers leave SUEZ and PORT SAID fortnightly for LONDON or LIVERPOOL direct.
Fare (home.) £10 Passengers returning by end October allowed 20% off outward fare (£14)
S.S. RANGOON 6000 Tons will leave PORT SAID about July 30 for Dover.
S.S. BURMA 5600 Tons will leave PORT SAID about August 11 for Devonport.
S.S. PEGU 5800 Tons will leave PORT SAID about August 18 for Dover
Due in LONDON or LIVERPOOL 12 days thereafter.
Apply WORMS & Co., Port Said and Suez. THOS. COOK & SON, (EGYPT) LD., CAIRO ;
G. J. GRACE & CO., ALEXANDRIA. 31-12-906

div.head: NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL, ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: First-class Hotel. Situated in Rosetta Avenue, the finest quarter in the Town. Two mintes from Railway Station. Close to Conservatory and the Opera House. Lift. Electric Light Throughout. Perfect Sanitary Arrangements. Magnificent Ball, Reception, Reading, and Music Rooms. Bar and Smoking Room.
FINE TERRACE ON THE AVENUE. - SPLENDID GARDEN. - OMNIBUS MEET ALL TRAINS AND STEAMERS. 31-8-906

GENERAL RAILWAY AND STEAMSHIP AGENTS. BANKERS.
BAGGAGE AND FORWARDING AGENTS.
Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their Passages, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.

CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe. Cook’s Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their travelling tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
FREIGHT SERVICE, Steamers leave Cairo every Saturday for Assouan and Halfa.
Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties.
Special arrangements for tour in PALESTINE, SYRIA and the DESERT, Lowest Rates.
Best camp equipment in the country!

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Venice every Wednesday about 8:30 a.m. in time for Express Switzerland, Paris and London leaving Venice 2 p.m. and 11.20 p.m. Arrival Trieste every Wednesday about 3 a.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m. Passengers from Cairo will find special through carriages and luggage-van attached every Saturday to Express leaving Cairo 9.30 a.m. and are conveyed direcly to Quay alongside steamer.
September 19 S.S. Habsburg Capt. Klausberger.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi & Trieste Line.

div.head: DES ENFANTS, LE DÉLICE!
div.p: C'est l'Emulsion Scott, si douce au palais que les bébés la prennent par gourmandise et si légère à l'estomac qu'ils la digèrent sans difficulté! Et quel bonheur aussi pour vous, chères mamans, d'avoir la réconfortante certitude de pouvoir, avec cette salutaire
EMULSION SCOTT,
le meilleur remède qui soit au monde, guérir toutes les affections dont serait affligé votre enfant :
DÉPÉRISSEMENT. ECZÉMA, RACHITISME. ACCIDENTS DE DENTITION. TOUX ET RHUME!
Exigez donc l'Emulsion Scott puisqu'elle est seule capable de vous assurer une guérison radicale!
En vente chez tous Pharmaciens et Droguistes.
Exigez toujours l'Emulsion avec cette marque : "le Pécheur", marque du procédé Scott !
BECK & CO’S PILSENER BEER
BREMEN.
Obtainable from every Respectable Firm In Cairo, Alexandria & the Sudan.
Otherwise apply to
V. J. FLEURENT, Cairo
F. MICALLEF, Sole Agent, 11 Bab Midan, Alexandria

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: The weather yesterday was very pleasant, though decidedly warm. This morning opens beautifully clear with a light N.W. breeze and a steady barometer.

table.head: OTHER STATIONS.
For the 24 hours ending 3 a.m. Yesterday

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette The English Daily newspaper, Established 1880. Editor and Manager - R. SMELLING Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIFF. MONDAY, JULY 30, 1908.
div.p: THE CRISIS IN RUSSIA.

Nothing is more remarkable about the present crisis in Russia than the closeness of the parallel between the course of events in that country and that of the great prototype of the Russian movement—the French Revo­lution. That the parallel lines may not be produced indefinitely mast be earnestly hoped, even by those who believe the most firmly in the righteousness of the popular cause and the pressing need of the substitution of the constitutional for the autocratic system. So far, however, the analogy has held good, and we have recently had a farther prolongation of the parallel. The Deputies have done almost precisely what the States General did 1789, that is to say that, having been excluded from their own House of Parliament, they have adjourned to another, and Viborg, in Finland, has supplied them with the Tennis Court of Versailles, whence they have issued a manifesto to the Russian people which may possibly stand in history as a landmark not less noteworthy than the ‘‘Ser- ment du Jeu de Paume.” The essence of that manifesto is an appeal to the nation to refuse to recognise the Imperial ukase dis­solving the Duma: ‘Russia must not re­main for a day without popular representation." Without the assent of the popular representa­tives, say the deputies, the Government has no right to collect taxes or to call recruits to the colours. "Accordingly, until the popular representatives are summoned, do not give a copeck to the Throne or a soldier to the army." It has been semi officially declared that the dissolution of the Duma "has not produced such an impression as the Press had foretold," and the new Prime Minister has telegraphed to the Paris "Matin" that "the Emperor is firmly and irrevocably determined to maintain the regime of national representation." M. Stolypin mast have what the readers of the “Matin" would probably call "an rude toupet" to say that Bat that sort of thing is just official Russia all over make-believe, ham- bag, sound and fury signifying nothing.

While it is utterly impossible to see any­thing ahead, through the darkness of the gathering storm, one can only note the effect of events in Russia upon public opinion outside. In London the dissolution of the Duma has been effected simultaneously with the gathering of the Inter-Parliamentary Union at Westminster, when the delegates were wel­comed by the Prime Minister, who rightly crystallized his sentiments in an epigram, “La Duma est morte, Vive la Duma: " It was a brilliant impromptu, and had, no doubt, been carefully thought out beforehand, but we must confess that we always feel a little nervous when a Liberal statesman assumes the part of the “mouton enrage." Sir Henry and his col leagues are men of peace—very much so. At the same time, one cannot forget the extra- ordinary propensity of the Liberal party to make up for its habitual apathy where British inte­rests are in question by an occasional excessive alertness where those of other nations are concerned.

It is impossible to foresee in what com­plications the Russian crisis may not involve certain Continental Powers, or what practical steps such Powers may not feel compelled to take in their own real, or pretended, interests. It is, therefore, eminently desirable that the British Government should preserve an abso­lutely free band, walk warily, and not allow itself to be morally committed to any line of action fraught with danger to the peace of Europe. The present crisis is one in which it is peculiarly necessary to keep a cool head, and to do nothing rashly. For, upon the events of the next few months may depend the future, not of Russia alone, but of the whole of that Europe of which Russia forms so large and so important a part. ("Pall Mall Gazette.")
THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE, MONDAY, JULY 30, 1906
LOCAL AND GENERAL.
Departure of Fusiliers.

The 1st Battalion Lancashire Fusiliers have been ordered to hold themselves in readiness to embark for Malta early in October next. Nile Valley (New) Company. The London Stock Exchange Committee have fixed August 14th as a special settling day in Nile Valley (New) Company, Limited- Further issue of 1,492 shares of £1 each, 18 paid (Nos. 216,766 to 218,257). Alexandria Municipality. As owing to the absence of a quorum, the meeting of the Alexandria Municipal Com mission called for last Wednesday was not held, another meeting will be held on Wednes day next, with the same ordre do jour. Our Berbereen. The campaign against unemployed Berbereen, which was recently commenced in Alexandria, has now spread to Cairo, where several of these undesirables have been arrested by the police. Bona fide servants are taking the advisable precaution to obtain from their masters cards certifying that they are employed, and it is only by such means that mistakes can be avoided. We would, therefore, advise all our readers who have servants of the Berbereen class to provide them with their cards certify ing that they are employed by the owner of the card, and we are sure that no inconvenience will result to those who follow this advice owing to mistaken arrest. 8t. Andrew's Boys’ Schools. The annual exhibition of these schools was held on Thursday, the 26th inst., in a large marquee which was erected in the playground of the High School in the Missala quarter. There was a very large gathering of the friends of the schools and of the pupils, who seemed thoroughly to appreciate the varied items on the excellent programme, composed of scenes and dialogues in English, French, and Arabic, the whole concluding with a musical sketch sung by the school choir, which did great credit to the training of Mr. O. Stanley Heaton. Consul General and Mrs. Gould were present, and the latter most grace fully presented the prizes to the successful pupils. The medals annually presented by Major Allan, Glasgow, for Bible knowledge, were won by Masters Petsakos (High School) and Hatwell (Lower Sohool). The exhibition of the pupils’ work, shown in a large room opposite the entrance, was unusually fine. The book¬keeping, especially, in French and English, showed most careful training on the part of the teacher, M. Corbo. We congratulate Mr. Buchanan on the pleasant entertainment which closed so successful a session.
PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.

Dr. . Keatinge, director of the School of Medicine, and Mr. H. M. Anthony, director of the Government Lands Department, arrived at Alexandria from Trieste this morning by the Austrian Lloyd's S.S. Semiramis, on return from leave. Rev. A. A. Cooper, M.A., of the British and Foreign Bible Society, sails from Port Said tomorrow by the P. and O. steamer Arabia for London, and will be absent about two months and a half. Mr. H. MacLoughlin, manager of the Im¬perial Ottoman Bank, Cairo, will be leaving Egypt on the 4th of August, by the Austrian Lloyd steamer, on a well-earned holiday of three months. The reception held by Mrs. Henry Lubbock at 82, Eaton-square, kindly lent by Isabelle Countess of Sligo, after the marriage of Mr. E. T. Richmond and Miss M. M. Lubbock, was very largely attended. Among those invited, of whom many were present, were Lord and Lady Avebury, Sir William and Ladyk Richmond, the Earl and Countess of Donoughmore, Lady Swansea, Lord and Lady Harrington, Lady Cavendish Bentinck, Sir Thomas and Lady Acland, Lord Edward Cecil, Admiral the Hon. Algernon and Lady Margaret Littelton, Mr. and Lady Margaret Nicholson, Mr. Justice and Lady Grantham, Mrs. Rube, Sir Walter and Lady Phillimore, Sir Arthur Birch, Miss Birch, Lord and Lady Llangattock, the Hon. Alfred Talbot, Mr. Cecil Chaplin, the Hon. John B. Lubbock, Sir Neville and Lady Lawbook, the Hon. Mrs. Norman Grosvanor, Mrs. Meyrick, Mr. and Mrs. Riversdale Gren fell, Master Grenfell, Mr. and Mrs. John Verity, Mr and Mrs. Grace, Adeliza Countess of Clancarty, and Lady Kathleen Le Poer French, and Mr. and Mrs. Ernest T. Richmond left later in the day in a motor car for States House, Medmenham, Bucks, kindly lent by Mr. and Mrs. John Verity. The marriage of Mr. John Schilizzi to Mile Helene Langhi took place yesterday afternoon at the Greek Cathedral, which was beautifully decorated for the occasion, A reception was afterwards held at the residence of the bride's ancle in Government Hospital street, and was largely attended by the many friends and relatives of the happy couple, who are spending their honeymoon at Aboukin. The wedding presents were costly and numerous, and included several cheques. Three months’ leave of absence has been granted to Mr. Burton Buckley, of the Minis- try of Public Works.
MEX ASSAULT CASE.
TRlAL OF THE ACCUSED.
SEVERE SENTENCE.

The trial of the two natives accused of assaulting Private O'Brien, of the Dublin Fusiliers, near Mex on the 21st nlto., began this morning at Alexandria in the Attarin Native Court. The Bench consisted of Judges Ahmed Bey Hilmi, Piesident of the Coart, Yoassef Bey Shawky, and Ahmed Bey Ziour. The Chief of the Parquet was Mohamed Bey Mahfouz. A representative of the Army of Occupation and Miralai Hopkinson Bey, Com¬mandant of the Alexandria City Police, were present. The President commenced the proceedings by asking the accused whether they had taken part in the assault. To this question both replied in the negative. The Chief of the Parquet then read out the indictment and gave a sum mary of the case wherein he showed that there was a strong chain of evidence tending to prove that Mohamed Ismail Kotb and Fayoumi Gabbari, the accused, were guilty of the crime imputed to them. He concluded his speech by asking the Coart to pass an exemplary sentence on the men as there was very clear evidence of their guilt. Private O’Brien then related the circum¬stances of the assault, his statements being interpreted to the Court. The donkey boy who accompanied O’Brien was afterwards called and gave his version of the affair, at the same time identifying the prisoners as the culprits. The advocate for the defence, Aly Bey Assem, then rose and asked Private O’Brien, who was allowed to sit down owing to the state of his health, whether he could account for all the money which he had with him when he started on his journey from Alexan-dris. Private O’Brien stated that he gave P.T. 2 to the cabman P T. 3 to the donkey boy, and P.T. 3 to the native who helped him to the camp after he had been attack¬ed. He started with P.T. 40 and arrived at the camp with P.T. 20, but he was quite unable to state how he had disposed of the rest of the money. Counsel then went on to point out that, although the alleged outrage had been perpetrated on Monday evening it was not until Tuesday evening at 10 o’clock that any intimation of the affray reached the caracol. Yet Private O’Brien was quite able on Monday to give a ver ion of the assault to Private Marvill (No. 3,706). In his statement he declared that the donkey boy, prior to the assault, had addressed some remarks to the two natives who were following him. This clearly showed that the donkey-boy, who might have had a hand in the assault, had recognised some others. In regard to O’Brien, he had declared to Blattner Bey, who translated his story, that he was unable to recognise the men who had attacked him. There were no other confirma¬tory witnesses and consequently the pro¬secution broke down on this question of identification. Why did not the donkey boy return to the nearest house and ask for help ? Probably the boy was particeps criminis and was concealing the truth in order to shield some of his friends, who were the actual perpetrators of the crime, O’Brien knew the donkey boy. When asked in hospital by the Chief of the Parquet to identify the accused, who were present by his bedside, he declared that one of them was the donkey boy, who did not happen to be present. On another day the accused together with the boy were con¬fronted with O’Brien at the hospital and he identified the donkey boy and declared that the other two men were his aggressors. This discrepancy shows that he was incapable of identifying his assailants. Moreover, when the coffee-shop keeper at Mex was asked about the accused, who were said by the donkey boy to have been at his cafe op that evening, he said that he had not seen one of them for three months, as he was keeping away because he owed him money. Kotb is in the service of the salt works and counsel asked the authorities to enquire of this man’s Employers as to his character. Kotb had willingly offered to be confronted with O’Brien together with five other natives as he was so certain that O’Brien would not identify him, but his offer was not enternained by the authorities. Counsel then triod to show that O’Brien, who had received his pay, had lingered in the city until 10 p.m. although he had been told to be back at 9 p.m. This point was overruled by the Court as being not pertinent to the case, and counsel was asked to refrain from this line of defense. The trial was concluded at 12.30 p.m , one of the accused, Kotb, being sentenced to 10 years’ imprisonment with hard labour and his accomplice to 7 years’ imprisonment with hard labour. A full report of the trial will appear in to morrow’s issue.
THE DENISHWAI EXECUTIONS.

Sir H. Campbell-Bannerman, in reply to Mr. J. Robertson, in the House of Commons last week, said the only time he could suggest for raising the question of the Denishwai trials and executions would be on the report stage of the Foreign Office vote, after the Home Office vote had been taken on Aug. 1.
STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
The Messageries Maritimes S. 8. Senegal, from Marseilles, passed tbe Straits of Messina on Saturday, and is due here to-morrow morning.
FRENCH IN EGYPT. CRITICISM OF ADMINISTRATION.

The following excerpt from a letter addres sed to “Le Journal” of Paris by “Un groupe de Francis habitant l’Egypte” may be of interest to our readers, who will notice that Judge Tuck is described below as an "English functionary,” and that the British officials of the Auglo-Egyptian Government are accused of a policy of opposition to French interests :— "We cannot admit that Europeans can be judged by natives on criminal charges. This may easily happen now that numbers of Egyp¬tians are trying to become naturalised British subjects (sic). The majority of the judges will certainly be English and the status of British subjects will certainly be safeguarded, but how about the other Europeans ? We have no inten¬tion of attacking England’s role in Egypt. On the contrary, we admire the improvements she has made and we wish to see her continuing her civilising work, but if France, by the con¬vention of 1904, renounced her secular rights in Egypt, it does not follow that French interests should be completely sacrificed. We are sincere partisans of the Entente Cordiale. but this “entente” is only followed loyally at London. Abroad and in the Colonies the British functionary, long since accustomed to oppose French interests, cannot make up his mind tD become the friend of his old foes. We have just had an example of this in the case of the Sucreries Company, in which magistrate began by demanding that the company should be declared bankrupt, only to contradict himself later by demanding of the Court a “concordat judiciaire” on the same basis as that which he had declared inad¬missible three months earlier. This is a strik-ing example of the attitude of British func¬tionaries. "French interests in Egypt are most con¬siderable. It is in France in which lie two- thirds of the Egyptian Debt, nearly all the bonds of the Credit Foncier, and the shares and bonds of the Saoreries and Raffineries. Numer¬ous deposits have been made daring the last several years and the important landed interests are in French hands. The total, at the least, is two milliards and a half, not including the Suez Canal shares, of which a large number are owned by Franca. It is these interests which a change in the regime would most seriously affect. Moreover, we are opposed to any modification or suppression of the Capitula¬tions, which would subject us entirely to the Egyptian Government. Lord Cromer is at present in England ; it is probable that he will ask his Government to call a conference. The interest of the conference would not seem to be great for England, which is mistress of all the wheels of Egyptian Administration. What Lord Cromer would seek is the personal satis¬faction of making Egypt into a British Colony, and so crown his work. "We count upon the vigilance of the French
FISHING BOAT DISASTER

The efforts to recover the bodies of the five Italian seamen who perished in the fishing boat disaster off the Abonkir coast a fortnight ago were finally crowned with success yesterday. The boat in which the unfortunate men were imprisoned was refloated, and it was thus possi¬ble to remove their bodies from the wreck. Owing to their prolonged immersion the bodies were in a very advanced state of de¬composition, and partly devoured by sharks. They were at once conveyed to the Govern¬ment Hospital, where the legal formalities were gone through previous to their burial, which will take place this afternoon.
THE LAW OF TRESPASS IN EGYPT.

In the House of Commons, Mr. Pickersgill asked the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs what was the outcome of the promise made by Lord Cromer in 1901, after the fracas near Cairo between British officers and the watchmen of Mr. Wilfrid Blunt, that he would consult the legal advisers of the Egyp¬tian Government as to the suggested strength¬ening of the law of trespass in Egypt, so as to protect native cultivators from injury at the hands of Europeans ; and whether any¬thing had been done in the premises. Sir E. Grey replied : Lord Cromer consulted the legal advisers to the Egyptian Government on his return to Cairo in 1901, and they were of opinion that no change in the law was necessary or practicable. Nor is there reason to believe that cases of trespass by Europeans are more common than cases of trespass by natives.

A CASE FOR ENQUIRY. To THE EDITOR OF THE “EGYPTIAN GAZETTE,” Dear Sir,—I most respectfully beg to inform you that on the evening of the 27th inst., whilst taking my evening walk from the French Gates to Moss Berth, I stopped to watch some native fishermen, 10 in number. Sud¬denly one in particular began up braiding some British sailors belonging to the Moss boats, informing them that in a year or two all Englishmen would be out up, and furthermore the language used was outrageous and if only these men knew what was going on I am afraid it would have ended very seriously. Police Guard No. 215 standing by suggested not in two years but in two months all Christians would be cut up. This looks very good for the Egypt at the same time. From Lord Cromer’s Quays police, however such was the case, and I Report we learn that the Government inspector hope this will be brought to his notice,—I had reported favourably upon the working of am, etc., our railways and the advancement of the Alexandria. J. ROBINSON. districts which they serve.
THE EGYPTIAN DELTA LIGHT RAILWAYS, LIMITED'. ANNUAL GENERAL MEETING.

The annual general meeting of the Egyptian Delta Light Railways, Limited, was held on the 24th inst. at Winchester House, Old Broad Street, London, E.C., Sir Auckland Colvin, K.C.S.I., K C.M.C., C.I.E. (Chairman of the company) presiding. The Secretary (Mr. F. J, Horne) having read the notice convening the meeting and the report of the auditors, the chairman said : I presume yon will, as usual, take the re port and accoonts as read. They refer to a period of half a year only, for which I pre pared yon at our last general meeting in January last. This fact, and the inclusion of tbe Helouan line (which, as I also then explained, kept its accounts previously in far less detail than we did) makes it impossible to effect the usual comparisons with the preceding corresponding period, but such as are practicable have been given to you in our report, and will now be so by me. The gene¬ral position is described by our agent in Egypt (Capt. Adams, R.E.) in a paragraph of his report to the Board which I will read to yon : "The net receipts for both the light lines and the Helouan branch are the best on re¬cord, being £6,901 and £5,432 respectively more than the corresponding previous half- year, that is, the results are 25 % better, as the net receipts increased by 28 % whilst the increase in open kilometrage was 3 %. It will be seen from the analysis of working that the receipts and expenditure per kilometre per week and per train kilometre, as compared with the previous year’s figures, are very satisfactory, and the proportion of expenditure to receipts for the whole system has it been reduced from 60 % to 55 %. I do not think better results could have been hoped for, and it should be remembered that the cotton crop, on which we depend for so much, was less than in the previous year, and that wages and other expenses, throughout the country, have in the last few years risen considerably.” I am sure you will regard this general state¬ment as satisfactory, and it is completely borne out by an examination of figures in our possession. If we take our light lines alone we find that onr earnings improved by Dearly LE. 10,000 and the expenses increased by rather less than L.E. 3,000 compared to the previous corresponding period. It follows that there was corresponding improvement in the net result, in the ratio of expenses to earnings, in the net receipts per kilometre open, etc., while it is no less satisfactory to reoord that our earnings improved under each main head of account. On the Helouan line our earnings increased by over L E. 6,000, and our expen¬ses by less than L.E. 1,000, so on analysis we get results even more satisfactory than on the Deltas proper, but the records of the previous period were not sufficiently complete same detail. Taking our passenger traffic we find an improvement in every class, giving us receipts 12 1/2% better in the case of the Deltas, and 10% better in that of the Helonan line than in the corresponding previous half year. In our goods traffic there was a slight falling- off from the carriage of cotton. We have no reason to regard this as likely to be permanent; on the contrary, we look to increased areas being brought under cotton cultivation, but it is satisfactory to note that, in spite of it, our earnings from oar goods traffic have in¬creased by about 8%, principally doe to bigger business in stone, so called manure, and fruit. The additional mileage opened during the half- year was on the Atfeh Edfina line, in the north of Egypt. We have commenced other extensions in the same part of the country opening op new territory to us. Progress on all the exten¬sions, of our light railways is going on satis¬factorily. On the Helonan line the additions being made take the form of doubling part of the road and providing necessary passenger coaches and goods wagons. During the half-year under review we have placed upon this line four first-class bogie carriages and twenty 15-ton stone wagons, which, I may say, have given entire satisfaction. For our light lines we purchased the rolling stock of the narrow-gauge line which previously existed between Port Said and Ismailia. It became available owing to the extension of the Egyp¬tian State Railways between these places on the standard guage, and we secured it on very favourable terms. As affecting the final result to the company of the half year’s working, I wish to remind you that the accounts we are dealing with are for the best half of a fall year. On the other hand, our expenditure on exten¬sions, mostly unproductive at present, will become productive daring the course of this year. Altogether 564 miles of line were open to traffic daring the six months. From this time we revert to accounts, etc, for the full year, commencing at the 1st April and ter¬minating at 31st March. For the current period the returns received from Egypt show that we have earned £403 more than in the corresponding 14 weeks of last year. I am also glad to say that there is a general expectation of what is called a good Nile this season ; and that there is probability of business continuing brisk in Egypt. On the other hand there has been some recrudescence of cattle plague. Our lines were visited by Mr. F. E. Robertson, C.I.E., C.E., one of our consulting engineers, in February last, and he was able to report favourably on their condition, and that of the rolling stocks ~ Our managing director visited I now wish to refer to what I will describe as the severance of the connection between this company and the Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Company. The Utter com¬pany was formed in April, 1904, under the auspices of our railway company, its operations were confined to lands in the proximity of our railways or their proposed extensions. Our company took up 10,000 of the land company’s first issue of shares of one pound each at par, and a similar number of its second issue at a premium of one pound per share, i.e., at £2 per share. As a consequence the direction and management of the land company was placed to a great extent in the hands of the directors and officers of the railways. The land company found it desirable to alter its memorandum of association and have its own management to attend to its important business. Its capita] had grown to a quarter of a million, its properties were scattered and required attention and development. We, of the rail¬way company, had already been asked to very seriously consider whether it was judicious to retain so large a holding in a land company which had gone far beyond its original inten¬tions, and we farther felt that we could not control advantageously the growing ope¬rations of the land company with a joint common staff, and that on the whole we had no right to oppose the reasonable wishes of that company. We were advised by our solicitors that it would not be feasible to alter our own Memorandum of Association sufficiently to enable us to hold shares in an independent land company, although the monies for the purpose were derived from pre¬mium on shares, and were consequently entirely at the disposal of the railway company. In view of all these circumstances we decided very reluctantly to sell our holdings in the land com¬pany and have done so at considerable profit which has been and will be credited to Share Premium Account. In ceasing to be a proprie tor the railway company put an end to such power of control over the land company as it had previously possessed. Your agent and general manager has now again, as his sole duty, to attend to the affairs of oar railways. The services of your former chief engineer (Mr. Peacok) have been placed at the disposal of the land company, for employment as their mana ger. In conclusion I have to refer with the deepest regret to the sad death of Mr. H. Turton Norton the senior of our firm of Solicitors. His assistance was invaluable to as in many difficult questions, and his loss to as is indeed great. THE CHAIRMAN: I now move that the report Of the directors dated 3rd July, 1906, together with the audited statement of accounts and balance sheet for the year ended 31st March, 1906, be and they are hereby approved, con¬firmed, and adopted. This was seconded by Sir Chas. Wm. Fremantle. THE CHAIRMAN: I now move that a dividend ait the rate of 5 % per annum for the half year ended 31st March, 1906, on the preference share capital of the company be and hereby is declared to be paid to the shareholders of the preference shares standing on the registers of the company at 23rd July, 1906, and to the holders of preference share warrants to bearer. This being seconded by Mr. Robert Miller and carried the chairman moved that Sir Francis L. O’Callaghan (one of the directors retiring by rotation) be re elected. This was seconded by Mr. Montaga Sharp. Mr. P. W. Carver and Mr. W. Pelizaena (two of the retiring directors) were then re¬elected. THE CHAIRMAN :—Gentlemen, in the report the firm of Messrs. Frank Davies, Meredith and Co. is mentioned as the auditors of the com¬pany offering themselves for re-election. Since the report was issued, that firm has dissolved partnership and the directors recommend that the firm of Messrs. Meredith and Co. be elected, Mr. Meredith, the head of that firm, having undertaken the personal supervision of the company’s accounts since its inception. The necessary resolution being moved and seconded , this concluded the business of the meeting.
NEW ABBAS THEATRE, CAIRO. DELLA TERRA ALLA LUNA.

The representation of Della Terra alia Luna by the Lombardo operetta company at the New Abbas Theatre, Cairo, leaves so little to be desired that it has been given on three suc¬cessive evenings, of which Friday was the first, before large houses, which on each occasion received it very well. Such a play is, of course an occasion for exceptional spectacular display, and in this Lombardo’s company seems to excel. The plot is known to all and was well carried out, while it is sufficient to say that the music is by Offenbach to convey the idea that it is bright and attractive throughout. The play contains twenty scenes divided into three acts, and the staging of all these was as perfect as we have seen in Cairo. The prin¬cipal characters were also very well given, without exception, and the thorns was dis¬tinctly less harsh and more evenly balanced than is the case usually. Both Signora Baldi and Signora Montis represented the parts of Fantasia and Carpaccio excellently, and Re When by Signor Pirracini and Misorospio by Signor Urbano left nothing to be desired. In fact in all the pieces in which these four artistes have appeared they have been seen to advantage and they are thoroughly deser¬ving of the applause which their appearance invokes. The dances in the second and third
SPORT AND PLAY. ALEXANDRIA SPORTING CLUB GYMKHANA.

A very successful Gymkhana was held on Saturday last on the grounds of the A. S. C. The attendance, which included H. H. Prince Omar Tonssonn, Mr. and Mrs. Gould, etc., was necessarily not large at this time of the year, but the entries were good and the competi¬tions keenly contested. The band of the Royal Dublin Fusiliers, by kind permission of Lt.- Col. Chapman and the officers, contributed to the success of the afternoon with a pleasing selection of music. The following were the events :— TENT PEGGING.—3 runs. 2 points for a hit, 3 for a draw, and 4 for a carry of 20 yards. Com¬petitors must gallop and not drop their lance until within a length of peg. There were ten competitors for this event and some good form was shown. The judges had not, however, any difficulty in awarding the prize to Captain Wilkins, who bad come down from Cairo to take part in the Gymkhana. The winner took all three pegs in finished style and we do not remember to have ever seen a better display of tent pegging at Alex¬andria than he gave. Amongst others who did well were Captain Jeffreys, Mr. Eiken, and Mr. E. A. Beuachi. TROTTING RACE.—For Arabs. To be ridden from Grand Stand round flag and back to winning post. Any horse breaking must pull up and turn round on the spot where be broke. Distance 3 furlongs. A large field started for this race and the lead was soon taken by Mr. J. E. Corniah, who maintained it till well after the turning flag, when unfortunately his pony broke and he had to turn round; Mr. Smithwick then assumed the lead and was never caught, though Col. Chapman might have made a near thing of it if his pony had not broken in the run in. POTATO AND BUCKET COMPETITION. - Each competitor to ride at fall gallop and drop a potato into each of three buckets placed at intervals. Three runs. Any competitor not riding at full gallop will be disqualified. The number of competitors reached its maximum in this event, as many as 22 taking part. The first to try his hand was Captain Jeffreys, who took all three buckets in good style, bat he was unable to keep up the aver¬age and the eventual winner was found in Mr. Jenkinson, who made a possible on each of his last two runs. If we mistake not this is not the first time Mr. Jenkinson has taken this particular event on the A.S.C.grounds. Others who did well were Mr. Eiken and Mr. Stuart. WHISTLING COON RACE.—Gentleman to run 60 yards, whistle tune to lady, who must write the name of the tune on paper, and hand the paper to the gentleman. The latter, whose pony will be held by the sais, will ride round a post to the winning post. The first in with the correct answer wins. This race afforded very considerable amuse¬ment, the efforts of the men after their brisk race on foot up the course to whistle the tones set them being very diverting. Mr. Macaulay was the first to get from his lady the written answer and was never caught, bat alas! the tune turned out to be other than had struck the ear and the winning lady was Mrs. Douglas Allen, for whom her husband whistled and rode away. BENDING RACE.—Competitors to ride their ponies in and out a row of flags, turning round the end one and returning the same way. Heats of 3. From a spectator’s point of view this was probably the most interesting event of the day. The race was run in heats, and the winners of the preliminary heats were Mr. Eiken, Capt. Crawley, and Ibrahim Bey Cherif; Mr. Logan, Capt. Wilkins and Capt. Jeffreys. The semi-finals resulted in Capt. Crawley and Capt. Jeffreys being left in to contest the final. In this Capt. Jeffreys, who bad all through shown the best form and looked like winning easily, unfortunately fouled one of the posts, and being, in consequence dis¬qualified, left Capt. Crawley to come in a winner at his leisure. It seemed to us that several of the competitors would have done better to have taken the race at a slower but surer pace, as the disqualifications were numerous. POLO BALL RACE.—Round a selected course. The last race was rather tedious for the onlookers, as it took the riders some time getting round the coarse, down the polo ground, and up the straight to the goal. The irrigation canal and training track had their fair share of attention and proved as effi¬cient bankers as they are accustomed to do at golf. The winners of the preliminary heats were Capt. Wilkinson, Mr. Stuart Mr. Eiken, and Mr. Jenkinson. The final produced an excellent finish, Captain Wilkinson only just securing the goal from Mr. Jenkinson. At the conclusion of the races Mrs. Gould very kindly gave away the prizes to the winners.

div.head: CARLTON HOTEL
div.p: Bulkeley (near Alexandria.)
Ramleh's Fashionable Hotel.
Patronized by the Elite.
Full Pension P.T. 50 a day. Visitors fron Cairo alight at Sidi-Gaber Station.
G. AQUILINA, Proprieter.
